Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Bridging Paleolimnology And Archaeology Through Human Biomarkers In Lake Sediment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding human population levels over time is fundamentally important for answering numerous questions about society?s deep past. For instance, were rising population levels responsible for spurring major social transformations, like the adoption of agriculture, more complex social and political hierarchies, or intensified warfare? How were population levels affected by major events like the colonization of new areas, environmental crises, or the collapse of states? Traditionally, archaeologists arrive at estimates of past demography through archaeological survey, but this is not always possible (e.g., for phases of human settlement with low population densities and high mobility, or in regions with poor surface visibility of sites due to thick vegetation or alluvial deposition). Paleolimnology, the study of lakes and other bodies of water , has the potential to provide relevant information. This interdisciplinary project aims to establish whether recently defined biochemical markers in ancient lake sediment can serve as reliable proxies for human population levels over time. P.I. Dr. Elizabeth Arkush, Co-P.I. Dr. Aubrey Hillman, Co-PI Dr. Josef Werne, and Co-PI Dr. Mark Abbott will use National Science Foundation support to analyze sediments in lake cores recovered in 2015 from small lakes in the Titicaca Basin of southern Peru. If successful, this technique will hold major potential for reconstructing the demographic histories of regions. In addition, because lake core sequences also have other significant information such as precipitation levels, this technique holds promise for investigating the relationship between human populations and environmental change by reducing the chronological uncertainty that comes from matching separate climate and population records.

Recent research shows that fecal ?stanols?, a class organic compounds deriving from feces of higher mammals, are present in measurable amounts in lake sediments. The presence and quantity should reflect human population levels in the lake watershed, particularly coprostanol, which is the major stanol type in human feces. This project aims to evaluate and expand the utility of this biomarker for archaeological research by comparing stanols in cores from two lakes in the south-central Andes with sequences of population levels derived from two completed full-coverage archaeological surveys. In addition to advancing new methodology for the reconstruction of past demography, the resulting dataset has the potential to make significant advances on questions about the connection between pre-Columbian sociopolitical change and paleoclimate. The project?s broader impacts include significant training and research opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This interdisciplinary project, based in the Lake Titicaca Basin of Peru, investigated recently defined biochemical markers in ancient lake sediment spanning several thousand years, in order to determine whether the biomarkers can serve as proxies for human and animal population levels over time. We also studied lake sediment chemistry to better understand climate and precipitation over the same time span. Overall, we aimed to achieve a better understanding of the long-term interactions between climate and human land use and social history in the Andes by examining several chronological sequences together: precipitation history, human demography and settlement patterns, and reliance on camelid herding (llamas and alpacas). The resulting dataset has the potential to make advances on questions about the connection between pre-Columbian sociopolitical change and paleoclimate.  

To capture biochemical markers and climate indexes over time, we recovered lake sediment cores from three small lakes in the Titicaca Basin: Lake Arapa, Lake Umayo, and Lake Orurillo. Our radiocarbon dates and age models show that the Arapa core record spans 1800 years, the Umayo record goes back 7300 years, and the Orurillo core covers 5000 years continuously up to the present. These records cover the majority of time that humans were living in the Andean highlands, and they include cultural transformations of central importance: the transition from hunting-and-gathering to farming, the rise of large, hierarchical societies, their collapse, the invasion of the Incas, and the invasion of the Spanish conquistadors.

Our results indicate variable levels of precipitation ranging from wet phases to very arid times. These climate episodes pair up with the well-established pre-Columbian history of the region in interesting ways. For instance, our data show that rising precipitation and high lake levels pertained during the initial transition to settled village life and domesticated crops, and the early rise of social hierarchies and large-scale religious monuments in this region. An episode of severe aridity, which is especially apparent in Orurillo lake core, coincided with the collapse of the Tiwanaku civilization on the southern shore of Lake Titicaca.This finding reinforces an important previous hypothesis that drought was a causal factor in the collapse, and contributes to our general understandings about the resilience or fragility of complex societies to climate perturbations.

A particularly exciting area of impact is the potential for elucidating changes in the intensity of camelid herding over time through biomarkers (i.e., camelid demography relative to human demography). We extracted a series of organic biomarkers deriving from feces of higher mammals from the Lake Orurillo and Umayo cores. Biomarkers from camelids and humans can be distinguished from each other, and both compounds are present in measurable quantities in these lake cores. Our analysis of biomarker ratios in the Orurillo cores indicate distinct fluctuations in camelid herding over time. For instance, the highest spike in camelid utilization is concurrent with an interval of extreme aridity, suggesting that people in pre-Columbian times shifted to a greater emphasis on camelid herding as a response to drought. This method represents a novel way for archaeologists to understand and reconstruct long-term histories of animal-human relationships. The project also included significant training and research opportunities for undergraduate students, graduate students, and post-docs.
